results.title: Gear VR
results.brief_description:
The Samsung Gear VR is a virtual reality head-mounted display mount developed by Samsung Electronics, in collaboration with Oculus VR, and manufactured by Samsung. The headset was released on November 27, 2015.

When in use, a compatible Samsung Galaxy device acts as the headset’s display and processor, while the Gear VR unit itself acts as the controller, which contains the field of view, as well as a custom inertial measurement unit, or IMU, for rotational tracking, which connects to the smartphone via USB-C or micro-USB. The Gear VR headset also includes a touchpad and back button on the side, as well as a proximity sensor to detect when the headset is on.

The Gear VR was first announced on September 3, 2014. To allow developers to create content for the Gear VR and to allow VR and technology enthusiasts to get early access to the technology, Samsung had released two innovator editions of the Gear VR before the consumer version.

results.title: House of Wax
results.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

constellations_primary.name: Movies on wax
constellations_primary.description: Waxing lyrical about the supernatural and early 21st-century teen stars.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.description: In the original trailer for House of Wax (1953), Warner Brothers heralded the third dimension as “the new wonder of the entertainment world”. Though that wonder had been discovered a year earlier in Bwana Devil (1952), Warner Brothers explored immersion further by releasing a colour 3D feature that incorporated stereo sound for the first time. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.

So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening tension and drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio. Both of these innovations are standard in filmmaking today.

results.title: House of Wax lobby cards
results.brief_description: Reproduction movie lobby card set for the promotio of the film ‘House of Wax’ a Warner Brothers production c1953. The set contains a series of eight colour pinted cards with illustrated scenes from the movie and graphic text noting ‘Natural Vision, Color by Warner Color, 3 Dimension, House of Wax.

results.title: Bwana Devil
results.brief_description: Filmmakers felt threatened by the arrival of TV in 1948 and sought ways to keep audiences coming to cinemas. One way was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film.

constellations_primary.name: Supplementing cinema
constellations_primary.description: A celebration of b-grade cinema's never-ending quest for more, more, more.

results.description:
“A lion in your lap! A lover in your arms! Newer than television!”

That’s what Arch Oboler’s Bwana Devil promised in 1952. TV had arrived in America four years earlier and filmmakers had started experimenting with ways to keep audiences in cinemas. One experiment was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film. At the time, industry bible Variety hailed 3D as “the next big thing”, and LIFE magazine captured the premiere with a major spread and this iconic picture of the audience. The film was panned by critics but made $2.5 million US dollars, something TV definitely couldn’t do yet.
description_for_label:

At the time, industry bible Variety hailed 3D as “the next big thing”, and LIFE magazine captured the premiere with a major spread and this iconic picture of the audience. The film was panned by critics but made $2.5 million US dollars, something TV definitely couldn’t do yet.

results.title: Bwana Devil 3D glasses
results.brief_description: Cardboard and plastic 3D movie glasses that fold open for wearing. Front centre has red printing ‘POLAROID’. Side arms each have red printing ‘Arch Oboler’s’, ‘ “BWANA DEVIL” in NATURAL VISION’. Left arm also has ‘Not for Sunglare or Night Driving’. Right arm also has ‘3-D Viewer No.718’.

results.title: The Power of Love
results.creator_credit: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

constellations_primary.name: The power of alternate endings
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation about alternate perspectives, dream states, sitcoms and spin-offs was made by Swinburne Cinema and Screen Studies student Daniel Bryan.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
results.description:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
description_for_label:
Though experiments into stereoscopic movies started back in 1889, filmmaker Edwin S Porter projected the first 3D test film in 1915. He used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour, that gave the illusion of depth when superimposed.

The same system was used for The Power of Love (1922), the first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience. And 3D wasn’t that film’s only innovation: viewers could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. It was the only film released using the Fairall-Elder stereoscopic camera pictured here.
